title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Good game if you like soccer, and the nerdier text based minutia that comes with running a sports team.

The actual match engine they use for the games is bad, like really bad. It is so bad that it makes you wonder why it is even a feature, it actually take away a lot from the game. If this game was strictly text based, it would be a 9.5/10 for me. The absurdity of the match engine brings it down to a 7/10 unfortunately.

Edited over a year later, with another 600 hours on 20: I was a little angry when I wrote this review. While some of it I still believe, this was before I realized you can actually alter the visual representation of the highlights (though still not scoring replays). I also have a more nuanced respect for the work that goes into making these engines. Also big ups for making this free.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I have over 3000 hours of Football manager hours, and i never get bored playing the franchise! 
So much freedom to do whatever you want, you can either start with a small unknown club and lead it to becoming one of the biggest and most successfull club in the world! Or you can start with one of the bigger clubs! 

The game is not only about finding the best players and signing them. You have to control your budget and make sure you stay in terms of the financial fair play rules! 

I havent bought the football manager 2020 yet since i still have great fun playing this one for now.. But i will definitely get the 2021 version when that one comes!

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
The FM series is like digital crack. FM19 is better than most of the previous iterations but arguably not quite as good as FM20. 

I wasn't even particularly into football before I started playing - it's an excellent strategy/rpg even if you ignore the football aspect (which it simulates brilliantly for the most part). You can manage in a variety of leagues from around the world, each with slightly different rules and challenges. This acts as a "difficulty setting" - you could choose a top team in a top league with fabulous wealth and world class players, who will probably win most games without needing much from you. Or you could choose a dirt poor team in a poor league which will require all kinds of managerial tricks and shrewd planning to succeed with. 

The game itself can be very daunting with the number of tasks you have to perform, but you can delegate most of these to your backroom staff (essentially automating it) until you feel ready to handle them yourself. This makes FM a fairly easy game to pick up but a VERY difficult game to master. You will still be learning new things after hundreds of hours. 

I'd recommend this game to anyone who wants to throw their life away.

review: The match engine is so broken, you need at least 30 shots before you score 2 or 3 goals. This happens in EVERY match. Doesn't matter how good your tactic or player is. Also, the amount of shots that hit the post is ridiculous. Example: I'm 48 matches in with Chelsea in my 3rd season with 1436 shots/ 733 on target/ 151 goals / 91 shots on post. Absolutely insane. If you are okay with this then you can still have fun I suppose.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
My first official Football Manager 2019 play through after learning the game:
- Load into custom club
- Create "Scouse FC" A team composed of only players from Liverpool, the area itself.
- Added former players such as Carra, Fowler and Gerrard to the field as my commanders for the youngsters (with the help of Workshop mods)
- Produced a hardworking but flair struck midfield composed of Curtis Jones, Stephen Gerrard, and Trent Alexander Arnold (After training to alter his position)
- Made a special exception for Ben Woodburn as he is just a quality player from the Academy and it's his only club. 
- Proceeded to play the Liverpool way with less regards to defense.
- Champions League Final Arrives.
- It's been a fair season so far and the final is Liverpool VS Barcelona (They had made plenty of great signings and look like a strong force)
- Half time whistle comes and it's 3-0. Liverpool is losing off of two goals from Coutinho and one goal for Mbappe.
- Me, your dashing manager, gives a rousing half time speech to rally the players to fight for the win.
- Gives instruction for the team to hard tackle Coutinho as revenge
- Fight back the 2nd half for a win and come back with two goals.
- The closing minutes of the game were winding down till Liverpool academy graduate Trent MF Alexander Arnold beat the defense and slotted the shot.
- Overtime commences.
- Both teams score but besides some early shots it was just two teams sluggishly but ruthlessly battling for the ball.
- Penalties...


- Barca proceeds to miss every single PK thanks to our dear Goalkeeper (Trial player from academy)
- Liverpool misses the first but scores all the rest

EASY DUB. 100% Recommend the game.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
My players get too many injuries easily despite I already reduced the training workload and tactics. I don't know if this is caused by bad (bug) match engine or I'm getting worse managing my players. LOL!

I don't care about the 3D engine because I like 2D view more as usual. But, the 2D view is getting worse, both the performance and the visual. I love the old 2D visuals which was more simple and clean.

There are already too many cons mentioned by other players, so I don't need to mention them here.

I still think FM2017 is better than FM2019, but I still recommend this.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: Have you ever wanted a game that so accuratley simulates modern football? Have you wanted to win the Champions League as Leyton Orient? Have you ever wanted to change the structure of a major football competition? It doesn't matter if you answered yes to all 3 questions, because Football Manager can do all 3 of those things and even more. This is the game where you can take control, and lead your team to victory. The learning curve you get when first purchasing the game is quickly mitigated when you achieve that immense feeling of satisfaction from watching your tactical style prevail over your opponents. If you've heard the phrase: "Football Is Life" then you will feel it in a game about playing virtual football.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: So far so good. Came to this from FM 2012 (best balance between complexity/depth and playability in my book), and I had been put off for a long time by the series' recent overwhelming feature barrage.  However, this surprised me: the tutorials were very informative and I got into a flow quickly (after a slow pre-season), the match engine runs reasonably well (and seems to be entertaining), and they have kept most of the best features I enjoyed while adding value. Only gripes are the annoying graphs (simple lines would do, what are these block colours...??) and the fact that player interactions still make no sense (impossible to keep them happy). Overall, a return to form

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
This game may as well be called, football team ignores manager 2019.

You tell your players to play it short, they boot it down the pitch and go route 1. Tell them to play a high line, they sit deep. Tell them to play offside trap and they sit back and let midfielders overwhelm them.

I've had enough, uninstalled and I will have to seriously consider getting any more FM games, i'll go back to 2017 and stick with that.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
ive always loved LMA games, so much i used to still play LMA 2006 (best ever manager game) up unitll this game came out, i used to buy up as many LMA disks as i could purchase online for my xbox. this game is as close to that version as possible. There are still some parts that i prefered on LMA (stadium build) loved that part picking different stands and stadiums and liked the sourcing and picking sponsorships. Apart from this, this game is now my favourite, i wish they would add a more in depth player role for both the stadium builds and sponsors. 
overall this game is brilliant

title: Football Manager 2019
review: Sucks away your life until you are all consumed by these 11 little men running around whilst you scream at your monitor. I go to work thinking about the next match, dream about how i can get the best out of my goal shy forwards, and dream of snatching up the next wonderkid who will take my team to the next level. This game is not for the casual gamer, its for people who are prepared to commit. The highs are great when your winning and the lows are real bad when your losing, i have been known to be i a foul mood post a 4-0 drubbing when i know my squad have not performed like they can. Great game, not sure my wife or family agree though....

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
This is the first FM I have purchases since FM 2014 and i'm astonished at how similar the match engine is, it's just meh. Outside the stadium this game can be a micro managers heaven, whilst allowing staff members to take these responsibilities if the player would rather delegate tasks. The transfer negotiation, contracts and player interaction is better than ever and the world in the game feels large and full of life. However, it all comes down to the pitch and this is where Football Manager fails.

Having played a few thousand hours on this engine, since it's release in 2011, I have noticed the match engine simply can't replicated the beautiful game in any convincing way. I could go through many reasons for my opinion on this, but I can sum it up simply by saying physics don't seem to apply to this universe, and it shows, the game looks like it should be from 1998 - 2004 and that's probably where we should send it.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
If you think about getting into the Football Manager games, I absolutely recommend it. Even if you don't like football, the games are still giving you a good gameplay experience as a slow strategy game. If you like slow strategy games, from tycoon games, to city builders, or grand strategy games, I think you will enjoy Football Manager. It has football flavour, and you will likely enjoy it if you like football as well, but it is by no means required to understand a lick of football before diving in.

If you consider buying this particular version of the game, only buy a new version of Football Manager every other year at the most. Going from 18 to 19 or 19 to 20 is likely not worth it. Not big enough difference to really be noticeable. But going from 17 to 19 is giving you an actually fresh experience.

review:
I Changed my review to a positive because this compared to all the other fms was the last more less playable fm in decades.
Won CL with KFC uerdigen twice , cl with dundee united 5 scottish leagues in a row first upon promotion.
The match engine was at times hectic from patch to patch and you have to find the right tactic that works best in europe (4-1-4-1 usually does it) but here if know what you are doing you could succeed.
Some patches were absolute hectic but in the long run this REALLY GOOD compared to that ROTTEN PISSSHIT 20.2 patch on fm 2020 .
On this fm skills do actually matter. Players actually MORE OR LESS did what their skills suggest when tactics got sorted. on fm 2020 patch 20.2 there ARE no good tactics , check fm arena , all of a sudden EVERY tactic got nerfed to uselessness.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Having been a long term player, I mean I have played the series when it was CM 93/94 on the Amiga I find Fm2019 my go to game to whittle a way a few hours.

Sure there is nothing amazing visually, but everything is neat and well presented.

I must say I preferred the layout from FM18 visually as it was just well neater and you could get more on the screen. 
But still it's fine.

As you would expect all the latest players are in the game, all the transfers, all the new young stars, all the old pro's.

The game plays out as you would expect without to many surprises.

As with all updates it took me a while to find the things I had got used to, I like to tinker with other teams and I find the staff screens a little more confusing (In the sense whilst it is easy to drill down and search for players with current and potential ability I can't seem to find where that has gone in the Staff side especially for managers? 
Oh well no biggie.

For me about this series it is about not breaking what works, the rest is fluff, I can't spare the time to manage all the training sessions, scouts and other things, I just want to tweak my team, find the odd player and pick a team and play a match using generic tactics with the odd tweak and whilst there is a lot in there that if you havent played the series for a long time will overwhelm you, you can pretty much get your staff to do all the bits you are not interested in and that eat in to precious game time!

So for me, the layout is a little more compressed than previous versions, FM18 had the balance right however the game seems to run a lot better than Fm17 (especially in game) so if you skipped a few updates this is worth picking up just for that.

Don't be put off by training, news and media, duties, tactics etc etc, you can set your staff to deal with 90% of it and just casually pick it up and play, you just need to tweak the settings a little and bang you are away!

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Manager induction is extremely annoying and seems not to be able to turn off. First of all, it's a tutorial. Just call it "tutorial" please. For those who are familiar with the Football Manager series, manager inductition is nothing but a time wasting excercise. For those who are new the series, an in-game tutorial is the least efficienct and effective way to learn the game. Just have a seperate tutorial.

Besides manager induction, there is not much new in this edition. The feature that the developers rave about is training. Well if you are interested more in being a member of the coaching staff than being a manager, it will be a thing for you. Another newish feature is tactical styles. It is not exactly new. Tactical styles are just pre-packaged sets of team instructions. The feature helps you save time. As such, it does not belong in the full-featured Football Manager. It is more of a Football Manager Touch stuff.

Please note that my review is based on the beta. However the commercial version is not likely to be any different other than having bugs removes.

1 YEAR ON UPDATE
The stable release version of FM20 came out yesterday. Having given it a try confirms my assessment of FM19. SI improved player development engine tremendously in FM19 but failed to make that an enjoyable part of the game. FM20 builds on that. In FM20 the manager can now make player development pathway an integral part of his man management.

I love this game! First off, the detail in this game is sensational. There is so much to do and the depth of everything is brilliant. Secondly, I personally love how you can start unemployed and work your way up the rankings. Next up - customisation. I love the customisation there is in this game and the detail you can go into. You could spend ages creating just your manager. Don't forget - you can also create your own club with your own players! Personally, I love this! Finally, just to keep this review fairly short because I could go on for a very long time about how good this game is, The user interface and background colours are really nice! 

Would definitely recommend this game!

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
One of the better modern incarnations of the game. Why?

Tactics feel responsive as do changes in games and the ability to play a certain way. As ever the game, is tricky to master but possible. It also seems representative the higher you start, the harder it is to sustain yourself. 

in addition, the features of Drafts and additional game modes add an intriguing aside. Albeit, to my mind slightly flawed. 

In short, this is the first time in a long time, I've played football manager and it's felt real and enjoyable. Of course, the repetition of conversations can get tedious, just as I imagine it does in real life football management. 30 years on from my first managerial simulation, I still punched the air in this one when the club I managed scored a later equaliser away to Barnsley, or when we knocked Chelsea out of the cup, or got promoted.

It's fun, if you like football and enjoying thinking through problems, as opposed to the more instant gratification of the more mainstream FIFA or PES. In fact, it's so good I don't really see the need to buy the new one.....which looks like mostly a data update.

9/10
- Just fell short of full marks due to the clunky-ness of some types of conversation and the additional modes needing a little work

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Milestone version in FM history! 
Never has Football (Soccer for you Americans) been simulated this accurately and never has FM been easier to pick up. Breathtaking 3D engine (for FM standards), streamlined UI and a plethora of tips and tricks in-game aswell as on the workshop or the internet.
Football Manager has finally become what many former Fifa Manager players wished for: prettier, slicker and easier to understand (with a multitude of tasks that you can just delegate to the AI). 

Now, you can really manage your club the way YOU want to manage it.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
"Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic".  The only reason this "game" works, is because you think it does.  There are so many options, customisations and unknowns that pretty much anything is possible, and when anything is possible, the only way to explain why that thing happened is by making excuses.

Lets say that the game engine is absolutely perfect for a moment (it isnt, but lets assume it was).  Well, then everyone playing it would be absolutely terrible at the game, unless they were actually a Premier League manager in real life.
So it can't be an actual simulation or it would be a nightmare to play, with all the players in the world shouting at the screen while Jurgen Klopp logged in and gave everyone a spanking.

However, what this game is NOT, is a game.  Because a game would be a simplified version of reality that gave the player a chance to shine in a field that they actually are not that good at, simply by learning the rules and using their brain.
Imagine a World War 2 game written with the same engine as FM19 and you'll understand what I'm talking about.  You are a completely inexperienced 18 year old from France, thrown into the trenches on the Western Front and given a rifle and no helmet, go win the war.  Oops, you're dead. Every.Single.Time.

So it is with FM19, it gives you the illusion of control of everything about a football club, and when something stupid happens (and it will, a LOT) then you'll blame yourself for your lack of skill/understanding and you'll either switch it off and go and do something productive or you'll keep playing and get more frustrated.  What you won't be doing is having fun.

I have a suggestion for the developer if they ever read these things.  I dont WANT to be an ACTUAL, real life, honest to goodness Premier League Manager.  If I did, then I would have chosen to do that in real life, and I probably would have been terrible at it.  What I DO want to do, is play a game that gives me a chance, and the illusion of thinking that maybe I could have been a Premier League Manager.  I want to look around for what I think are decent players, buy them cheap and put a system together that - if I follow the in game cues, generally gets me winning.

I really don't see the sense in the frustrating and annoying parts of this game, whereby - for example - a non league team on a 5 game run of abysmal results, with no manager and a 15 year old defender up front, can hold off the European Champions, 35 shots on target from an $80m front man and then win by two goals in the 95th minute.  Presumably because the manager chose the wrong option on an obscure Press Conference page saying that he was "Pretty confident that my $1bn team will spank these dirty hoof merchants".  What follows is then the game of their life for the hoof merchants and $1bn of football talent that, suddenly, inexplicably, cannot pass, head or weirdly, even run fast.  That, is not and will never be fun.

Would it be SO BAD, to let us actually give those non leaguers the thrashing of their lives?  Would it be so terrible to allow people a quiet smile in their darkened bedrooms as their fantasy football team spanks Worcester Western Terriers 83-0?

I go back to the quote at the start of this review -> "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic". 
 Could the above scenario have happened in real life?  Sure.  Has it happened in real life?  Maybe.  Is it fun to spend your precious leisure time feeling like you don't understand and just aren't clever enough to play a game that you spent money on?  No.  And since most people don't like to assume they are stupid and below par they will predictably blame the game for their problems.

Buy at your peril, you will feel worse about yourself having purchased and played this game.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
really amazing game but still there are certain problems to be corrected in 2020:

- A lot of balls hit the woodwork, not realistic at all
- I can sense if I will win according to the match engine or I will draw no matter how many shoots I take. Not realistic at all, out of 40 shoots 2 should be goal at least or should not be able to shoot 40 times.
- VAR animation is completely unnecessary, should have the option to cut the scene and get the result directly, in matches you dominate it gets really boring to wait
- VAR checking if in the box or out is totally irrelevant, it s always outside the box
- My love is Trabzonspor and I will never manage another team except national teams BUT even if I manage it so well and increase the budget like a lot, I can never compete with top teams. This is unrealistic, at least after 5-7 years I should be able to compete with them.
- Players cannot develop after a point if they are in a certain league and not at the best one. This is not realistic as well, of course there are differences between the quality of the leagues and the players MAY not be as good as if they were in premier league for instance BUT the differences should be minor and MOST players should be able to reach a similar potential. IMAGINE a star player spending his life in Trabzonspor. This talent MAY (or he may still be) never be as good as Mo Salah BUT there is no reason for him not to get very close to Salah. In the current game, it is impossible!!
- Player ratings drop for no reason and most players do not even reach their potential no matter what level of training facilities, coaching team you have. If they are in Turkish league instead of Premier league they for sure deteriorate easily to STICK to your unrealistic development system both in actual rating and in potential rating. This is not logical, there is no reason for the players to deteriorate so much in reality. Particularly for players with determination above 15!

Those are all critical changes that you must include. I am confident that they are all necessary if you want to make the game even more fun and realistic.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Judging by my playtime, I like this game - and it is true. It can be very annoying at times though, and I don't even mean injuries or the fact some players want a contract renewal (to receive moar!!) every few months. What I hate are hidden scenarios, by which you should lost points at some spot no matter what. I save - load (or do scumsaving - whatever, I play for my personal fun, not for any bragging), and I sometimes find myself playing against way worse opponent for five, six times - which is happening right now too. I mean, my second squad have just beaten Napoli in CL 4-1 - how can my best squad (which means "with all my best players") be so impotent against Real San Sebastian? I could understand problems against Barcelona or Atletico, but Real San Sebastian? Really? And in the same way you may beat that San Sebastian 7-0 the other day, where you may have to restart because of injury and it will be 8-1 then. I think they overvalue some reasons calculating outcome, like maybe in my case of now San Sebastian really wants to defeat me because one of their ex-players is playing for me now. In real life such things never boosts any team that much!
Another thing I really dislike about this game is the fact you may click on some add and any sort of scum may open in your web-browser. Again, I just play for fun and in that time I don't want to care about some prostrate cancer at all, let alone read about it in my browser.
So, nice game for those who have fantasy and love football, it could easily be better though. Next version pre-ordered, anyway.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Almost a 100 hours for this shitty ME edition and i despise the game play. it's monotonous, bland and painful to get through.

It has been overstated  by the true followers of this series that the FM12 edition delivered the best playing pleasure and a match engine manageable for you not to frigging lose your mind. I played FM12 from November 2011 till January 2017 and didn't wish to stop. FM17 also had fairly palatable ME but from FM18 it all tanked and FM19 was like the developers completed the destruction of the ME that began FM18.

Some plus to SI for adding tactical styles to FM19 , this was genius as it really made tactics and strategy fun and exciting but the inability of the ME to translate this styles to the game play in ME is main fly in the ointment. Maybe it was a rush job but this edition left me really dissatisfied.

SI should invest in fixing the match engine, even if it takes building it from the scratch all over, heck it costs 50 quids and they sell boatload every year.

With the most unambitious AI teams with defence strategies  and defensive 4-1-4-1 formation that produce 1000s of blocked crosses and shots to the voodoo AI counter attacks that produces goals for the opposition all the time to the shitty graphics and animations...this is impossible to recommend.

not fun at all Sega, what's the point in making a game this unfair ????

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
It is pretty standard FM really. Does what it says on the tin, very similar at its core to older titles. It is solid, but I think I have reached a breaking point mainly as persistent issues remain. 

   Some irritants then (albeit nothing new hence the initial comment): Shots on Target ratio (you vs. opponent) gets really noddy over time. Not un-common for the AI to score 1/2 goals out of 2 or 3 taken, and then my Spurs team to fail to score with nearly 20 on target - thats with Kane up top whose finishing and composure are meant to be pretty decent. You also seem to hit the woodwork an insane amount, I have literally counted 11 times in 3 games - a semi final and then two key league games. 
   Add stupid amounts of training injuries (with light workloads). My record in a week is four: a fractured skull!?! 2 twisted knees from sprinting and bruised ankle. Player contract requests are a mess, they keep asking for new ones with no logical reason. I.e you grant one, then 2 months later they are now apparently far better than when they just signed their most recent one. Not being funny Jan you are 34 and actually worse. Do these make it unplayable? No.  Do they make those lovely long saves I used to really get into viable? Also no. 

Plus - get ready to concede on the break. All. The. Time. It is unavoidable, repetitive and happens multiple times a game.  Seems to be little tactical variation in opponents. Just gets boring over time. 

I think its time these underlying mechanics are addressed by SI, rather than the fugly skins, avatars and scouting menus that did not need changing. First new FM since 2015 and it is a little disappointing. Worth the discount sale price though.





UPDATED: 

So after far too much free time recently I have been playing a fair bit. Just to give some statistics calculated from my last 5 games, two of which against 20th and 16th at home in the PL. 9% of my shots have been on target. And of these, only 12% have resulted in goals. That is frankly ludicrous when considering the stats of the players in my starting line up. In-fact that has to be scripted and broken. To compound the issue, 63% of the opponents shots are on target, of which a whopping 74% resulted a goal. Of these goals they are nearly always on the break, or a cheeky effort from 25 yards. Opposition forwards are inexplicably un-marked on the half-way line, one bloke attacks the win and squares it. Goal every-time. This happens even on a 'defensive' formation setting, so why the team is all committed only SI knows.

I am currently losing a player a week to some stupid injury gained whilst sprinting in training. Nothing major usually 1-3 days, but its always conviniently the day before a game, when the workload says they are not even training. On top of this, it seems to be the same position too, so you quickly run out of options even if you have at least two solid choices. It has intensified as I enter the business part of the season and chasing a 3 point gap to Liverpool at the top. I want to re-iterate, I am still winning titles etc, I rotate players, I know what I am doing basically but this has to be broken, its not fun to play when it starts being so clearly to me anyway, scripted. And don't mention the contract renewals, again that has to be a bug. Its noddy as hell. To top it all off, they must know this is broken, but they cna put adverts for FM 20 into the game. Not good.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: This is the first FM I've played since FM2015 having resisted newer iterations simply because I didn't have the time or motivation to go through the same learning curve to have some joy with the game. I've been playing this for a few weeks now, and I have to say I am bitterly disappointed. Why? I'll tell you why - the match engine. It's an absolute shambles. Having decided to take on the lumbering giant Newcastle Utd, my second game of the Premier League season was against Man City. A tough proposition. Well, somehow, by halt time I was 6-2 up. Yes, 6-2. And all six of my goals came from outside the box. 6 absolute worldies. This should have felt amazing, but as every single shot flew into the net my heart began to sink. This was just silly. Sillier still, the game ended up in a 7-7 draw. Every game since then has resulted in high scoring games. Seemingly most direct free kicks fly into the goal, most long range efforts result in a goal and occasionally, VAR is consulted for no apparent reason whatsoever. Animation is dreadful, almost retrograde from the 2015 release. I'll be looking into a refund. Although it may be too late - given I've played it for a week or so desperately wanting it to drift back into something more realistic. Very, very poor.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Having played Football Manager consistently since FM 2008's release, I've noticed that some games from this franchise are varied, challenging and fun. Other games, however, can be easy to 'cheese', in that a certain tactic or type of player can be exploited for massive gain.

Football Manager 2019, on the other hand, is an exception to the rule. It's repetitive and difficult to find a working formula because every game, regardless of tactic, plays out the same. You instruct your players to build patiently, working the ball through the middle of the pitch, waiting for that key pass to unlock the defence - what this translates to on the pitch is for the ball to the played out wide and crossed in whenever possible. You change your tactic to be a fast counter with a target man laying off the ball to your inside forwards - what this translates to on the pitch is for the ball to the played out wide and crossed in whenever possible. It is a fundamental flaw that makes matches difficult to watch, much less win through tactic prowess.

Aside from the match engine, the off-the-pitch interactions and dynamics with players, other managers and agents is a rewarding and much-needed aspect for a true managerial simulation. These aspects of the game are often improved year-by-year as they become more polished. The fear that arises is that it could become unreasonably time-consuming, creating larger gaps between match days with excessive busy work. Hopefully Sports Interactive acknowledge this and keep it under control.

Overall, I don't feel like I can recommend this game based on how bland and monotonous the game engine makes match-days. I very much hope that it's either tweaked for 2020 or completely reworked, however, I understand this is big ask given the yearly releases.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: Definitely worth the buy. It's quite an upgrade from the recent iterations and I'm loving the new features introduced. Only issue is with match engine, but it is still better and more dynamic. The team dynamics and in-depth training adds a new dimension to managing a football club and this added challenge makes it more enjoyable and addictive. Best improvement is in the Tactics dept. for customising your own by building up on existing presets available and it gives feedback on team dynamics and opposition strengths/weakness in different areas of the pitch. The separation between on-the-ball, in-transition and off-the-ball is helpful to fine tune your system to match real world game or try and eke out a small advantage in gameplay. As I said, definitely worth a buy!

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
A solid entry in the series. I've played every iteration from FM 11-19 with the exception of 14,17,18. This one is one of the better ones. People complaining about the match engine are expecting too much, you will always see some unrealistic things happen and every version has its quirks about what works and what doesn't (example: in FM 13 tall players with good heading were unstoppable, per mertesacker made world team of the year for me). In this one I haven't really noticed anything too glaring. 

I've seen a lot of reviews that say "crosses don't work" and "my defenders are useless," I honestly think most of these players are just bad. In my second season I have more goals from crosses than anything else and the second best defense (as Lyon in the French League). I think a lot of these players don't know who to buy, how to set up their team, etc. Not that I'm some expert, but I've been far more frustrated with previous match engines (12 and 16 in particular).

My biggest complaint is a bug that I only I seem to have - the first goal in almost every match is accompanied by the offside whistle, whether or not the goal was offside. That and the player interactions are just horribly written and nonsensical, just expect to have 2-4 players angry at you at all times for things that will be out of your control. Other than that, it's a solid iteration and I plan to skip next year's and keep playing this one.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I am an absolute no life on football manager, And I will still play the games regardless of my opinion. But this game is solidly the worst out of the last few years. The match engine is absolutely awful, defenders won't stick to their player even if you tell them to mark tight, Attackers with very high finishing will consistently fail to score, And substitutes usually don't do anything. Your other option is to play a match with instant result, Which takes out any possible excitement over what happens because 99% of the time you will win if you use it. And something else I've noticed is all the random little features they have removed since fm17. You can't simulate your match anymore, England's under 23 league is now non competitive so you can't actually know how good your under 23 players are doing in the league accurately, there's so many random little things that you don't care about individually but when you add it all up the game just feels emptier than the older ones. FM20 has recently been announced so hopefully they don't lazy out this year and maybe bring back some of the things they've taken away, make the match engine better, add some new features that don't make the game more tedious but make it worth buying.

I'm not an expert critic, but you don't have to be a chef to say the food sucks.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Match Engine is a mess. It's far too easy to park the bus. Crosses constantly get blocked, world-class full backs deliver crosses like brainless idiots, one-on-one chances against goal keepers are far more difficult to be converted into goals than your stupid 30-yard-out long shots, and whoever shoots in the 12-yard box can expect 9 out of 10 block by a defender. How could SI fuxx up the simulation that much? 
Having played the FM series for 15 years and I would say FM 2019 match engine is by far the dumbest version.

title: Football Manager 2019

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I really enjoy playing the game and I recommend you buy it If you plan to manage a club, If you plan to manage an international team however, I would recommend you don't buy the game. The international management part of the game has very few features, if any, and is just awful.

I do wish there were more options to modify the UI without loading 3rd party skins, more interaction with your players and staff (Yaya Toure once lost it with Man City because they didn't wish him happy birthday so you'd expect such a feature to be in a game like FM right?), ability to adjust the database as you go on through a save and some others but these are small annoyances and the rest of the game more than makes up for these for me.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Once you become unemployed, you cannot get a new job at another club. If you have said something to the management, it follows an ongoing conversation in every job you seek in a new club.

Even when players feel ill-treated, you do not have the tools to do well again.

You answer questions about new employment in many jobs and you get no new job no matter what you say, it is a bad thing about the game you have spent a lot of hours to no avail. And you have to start all over again.

I miss the tools one does as a manger to correct misunderstandings between players and management. there are so many gaps in communication between management and player - manger. it would be great if you could fix it. You guys who made the game. Sega

Michael

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Here's the problem with modern FM - You sit around way too long waiting for games, as the game processes way too much information all over the world.
For a while, you don't mind. You carry on building your team and battling away. But when you've done all this and just need to get on with the game, it starts to grind.
It's a very detailed game, and that's becoming it's downfall. It's losing the fun factor to accomodate the realism card.
Not once have I looked at my medical room. I honestly don't care about this. I don't give a damn about the social media aspect, or the press. ( yawn )
I buy or produce players, tweak the training and set a formation. That's all I want to do. If a player is injured, then fine, but I don't need all the rubbish about it. Just tell me when he's back.
FM needs to get back to it's roots, providing fun gameplay, not waiting about for 15 mins between games.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
An old school gamer from Premier Manager '98 reviews FM19 after FM17.

The biggest IMPROVEMENTS are:
- Highlight details during game,
- Finally, useful suggestions from your assistant on tactics improvement...
- Some training features,
- Staff decision on out transfers (can be changed to you as manager) and watch out on low release clauses...

The biggest FLAWs are:
- Criminal initial price of 55e, 
- Slow gameplay pace became even slower with highlights and training. So, you'll HARDLY finish one season playing less than 70 hours, 90% of the time out of matches ...
- Faces - so ugly with graphics from '00s, false badges and shirts even in 2019 !!! (better no faces at all)...
- Overcrowded inbox with over 90% useless information...

Overall 7.9/10, BIG STEP FORWARD but still not worth 54,99e, recommended only on 75% SALE...

Thanks.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Hello,
I need help. 
I have bad team characters and players' faces don't know what it may be?
developer_response:
Hi,

If you are having issue with the players' graphics, we would suggest you to delete your caches and preferences and see if it help.
 
- Click ‘File Explorer’ from within the taskbar (or click ‘Desktop/Start’ then type in ‘File Explorer’)
- On the header click ‘View’ and make sure above ‘Show/hide’ that ‘Hidden Items’ is ticked
- Navigate to C:\Users\[Your Windows Username]\AppData\Local\Sports Interactive\Football Manager 2019
- Delete the Preferences and/or Cache folder

If you are still having issue with the game, please contact out support team at help@sega.co.uk. 

Thank you.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: Personally, I can see the appeal to this game but it simply isn't for me. From what I could see, it would take me hours just to learn how to play the game and I can't see myself spending all this time on a game that I might not even enjoy. If you love micromanaging and love soccer, then this game is for you but I don't enjoy those things enough to spend hours on the game. If you are like me and bought the game to just have some fun for a little while then I wouldn't recommend it.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
In one word - horrible. 

Game feels scripted, player morale has far more effect on match outcomes than anything else - for example if your team's morale is less that "okay" you will lose to teams 5 leagues below you easily. Even worse than this, once your team's morale is low you will keep conceding the same goal for x number of matches. Sometimes it's a billiard style goal after a set piece, sometimes it's a direct set piece goal, sometimes one of your defenders will keep making penalty fouls for 10 games in a row. 

This game is so bad that one must wonder if it was ever tested by a QA team because flaws are so fundamental and instantly visible. This is not a matter of making mistakes because something is hard - this is just not caring about your end product because there is no competition.

In game feeling is like you have absolutely 0 impact on anything that happens in game. It feels like engine decides if its gonna kick you in the nuts or not completely randomly. 

People told me not yo buy this and i did not listen - do not make the same mistake. 

Do not buy this, i bought it on sale and regretted it less than 48 hours later. Worst spent money and time ever.

And once again do not buy this shit. I have never felt more cheated after buying than after buying FM 2019.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: I've played since 2010 and i am under the impression the AI in this one is pretty unfair. I like it but it will not last if it keeps being seriously unfair. Me: no luck. Adversary. Opponent: all the luck in the world. My goalkeeper: the most incompetent player around. Opponent: Spiderman in the goal. It's just no fun. And if i manage to win against the unfair AI it's with 1-0. Nice. And than there is the VAR. Not only is the animation pretty annoying it's used way too much. And even obiously no offside situations are offside according to the VAR. The VAR always is against you.  Very little improvement in this version, only more irritation. And if you are not allowed to win, you wont. No matter what you do. Your strikers will hit the post, the bar and the keeper on the other side is superman. And than there is the AI. All it does is react. It's unable to anticipate en that often gives problems.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: I think I have a problem

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I finally gave it a solid go. It's not perfect but it's by far the best FM made.

I just hope for the next few iteration sof this game they improve the 3D engine, especially all the clunky animations. I hope they look into the excessive corner kicks and the crazy amount of 90 minute goals that happen week in week out (not just for my team but around every league).

I also hope they tone down the media - because I can always make my rivals lose by praising them and making them complacent.

Sometimes the game is absurdly easy and at times it's randomly difficult - to the point it makes no sense. 

Also they need to look into the "promises" in this game. I signed a world class player, promising we would "win the UCL". We lost the final becuase of so many injuries and a red card.  Now the player is eternally unhappy - its been 6 months and he is still unhappy - his morale is very poor and he just plays crap. I have no way of talking to him this entire time and no way to tell him "look we lost the final, it was bad luck - lets keep on working toward winning in the future"

Nope, it won't let me even communicate with him.

This is leading me to wanting to buy the editor just to remove that unhappiness because it's unrealistic. It makes me feel like some things in this game are annoying this way because it drives sales of the $7 and overpriced editor - which should be included FOR FREE as the game is already expensive as it is.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I hate talking to the media, it's always the same - also appears to have zero impact. Yes you can delegate this facet of the game to you assistant, but why have it in at all?

The tactics format is better, probably the best I've interacted with - it is not simple, nor too complicated, but as a manager you truly want to stamp your own philosophy on the team, this is the magic of Football Manager, and so I appreciated the improved tactics aspect. In truth, I'd like the tactical side of the game to become even more in depth and complex. If you want to build a philosophy, you must be willing to engage with a more complicated tactical set up. 

Injuries! I have often experienced that you'll have a player, call him play Z, he is in your first team squad, but he doesn't get anywhere near the first team, he never gets injured. But, if you put him into your starting 11, I swear he'll pick up an injury two days before the match. I think a lot of FM is scripted, we deny this to ourselves, but some results are just predestined. I guess in an effort to make the game 'more exciting'. 

Transfers - absolute nonsense - you are a mid range Premier league club, you will offer £15million + generous add ons for a £4million rated youngster, the owning club will reject you. Then you'll see some random club like Swansea paying £7.5million for the same player!!!

A good game, but not perfect.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Having never played this game before, I was really hoping that it would be an awesome game. It is super boring, repetitive,  and quite literally just email simulator 2019. I played as Chelsea and let me tell you........ How many times have you seen two injuries and a red card in a match for the same team? Because that is all this game is! in one half season, I have had more injuries than I can count (yes, I know not to push the players in training, yada yada yada) and nothing short of 10 red cards. Are you kidding me? When you constantly get whacked like a willy against the 20th place team, it gets old. It sucks too because I really was hoping that this game would be the one (got tired of how bad FIFA career mode is).

In short, I was really disappointed with how this game plays. Same ole "just add in every injury for every player" difficulty setting makes it hard to play, and is just down right goofy. You will find yourself laughing at how ridiculous the game is in about 20 minutes. The end.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Engaging and annoying at the same time. Could be much better and hints could be more constructive. Player traits could be explained more. I had to check everything and finally i googled that you can't train heading. My backs had really poor heading...and really hate when any game forces me to google with no serious reason. This was just childish.

I had to put over 20 hours just to get almost relegated to test and confirm what attribute counts for what. I could save/load sh*t, but this just kills the enjoyment. The biggest fail of the game is the description, there is practically none. I had few stupid fails like passing directly to opponent, fouls for no reason, passing back to goalkeeper with for like penalty shoot. The problem is that I don't know the reason. Engine should be explained more. 

I am rather sligthly positive to neutral about the game. For me it's just another decent game.

You just need to waste so much time to grasp basics and even then not everything seems logical.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Well. It has been 5 years since my last experience with football manager.

I decided to give it a go in order to play with a friend of mine.
First match I got to play against him after 4 months (in-game obviously) and the game freezes. Can't continue in any way.
I go on and google the bug and I see that it is a common occurance for the 3 last years.
I was enjoying myself up to that, but this really stroke a nerve. You decide to take the game to steam, you disable direct lan play, you enable all type of annoying DRM's. You make in-game editor a DLC.
I was ok with all of those, I've been playing since 2002 when it was called Championship manager.

You are aiming to multiplayer but when someone does play it, there is a problem that keeps on going for 2+ years? REALLY?

Don't buy it if you plan on playing with friends. Should it freeze once more, I'm filing for refund.

review: I had a lot of misgivings about this game, playing it for the first time, but I have come to the conclusion that it isn't that bad. title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Performance is much better and I'm playing on a low end PC, anyway. The previous one (FM 2018) used to take ages for me to process day to day. Love the new tactical customizations and the training. Much easier to understand for someone like me who just got into the franchise last year.  If you're new and you want to get into the game this year's series is the right one to pick. Finally added the tutorial.

However apart from those not so much has changed so if you played FM 18 and maybe you're thinking of saving money you might not need to buy this one. I think its better to buy a new FM every 2-3 years since the changes are not too significant year by year. Although if you're an FM hardcore you might still going to pick it 😂

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
new year, same shit.

the core game thats been unchanged for last 10 years is still robust as ever, but these needless changes to systems that were never a problem and not fixing or expanding ones that are is wearing thin.

tactics have got streamlined over the years and feel more general, and this year has changed again, but im not sure why because the system isnt any better or easier to use. 
same goes for training, its become more obtuse, and i cant see how it benefited from the change besides trying to look like they added something new
why change it when the match engine still looks like headless chickens running all over the place?
it breaks immersion when you see a CF run in a circle or miss point blank for 7th time in a row. always having 26 shots vs their 3 but losing 1-0 grows old.

id like to see how a teams countering us and use the match day engine to change my tactics, but what you see doesnt have any relation to the tactics, its just an abstract screen with players running around.
often i see my teams destroying theirs, peppering the goal but not scoring, but i have no options left because what else can you do if your strikers keep missing sitters?

ive only played 5 hours of this version, and i tried to get a refund but id played longer than 2 hours. 
but to play a couple of games and set up everything takes longer than that so im stuck with it.

i would have prefered to give this a neutral rating but you can only give up/down vote.
i just wish they would make the 3d match engine look better, fix the algorithms of the players so they look like human beings who are professional footballers. 
make meaningful changes that impact whats already there
and dont streamline or complicate but give more options and make them easier to use.

i hope i havent come off to hard to please but i have played these games for years and lost interest last 2-3 years.
hope they can pick it back up

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
This is my first time playing a sports management simulation game in over 10 years, and it was a bad experience.  I felt thrown into an interface with hundreds of buttons and there doesn't seem to be any introduction to where to go or what to do.  Spent a couple minutes reading, but there was so much information with no context that I was forgetting it as fast as I read it.  I apparently have to opt into advertising, which confuses me because I'm pretty sure I paid money for this game and I don't usually have to watch targeted ads when I pay for games.  The default character looks like an unhealthy mime and after fidgeting with it I still couldn't get it to look like a human.  Eventually after clicking around looking at words and buttons and not figuring anything out, I gave up and exited.  Also, there's either no sound or the sound didn't work (worked on the last game I played and the one I played right after).

Perhaps seasoned veterans of management/simulator games that already know what to do would enjoy the game, but as someone who isn't specifically a fan of this genre and thought it looked interesting when it popped up in my discovery queue as a highly rated sim game, I didn't enjoy the experience.

Bottom line: the ad is not reflective of actual game play, and it's not beginner friendly.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Of all the Football Manager games that I have played, this has the dumbest AI. And I played them all in the last 7-8 years.
Let me give you an example. I start the season with FCSB in Romania. At half season, 5 regular first team players who got to be in the first team in every single game until then start crying that they want to leave because they don't get enough first team. I continue to play them in every single game, they are still unhappy because of lack of first team. At half season, there is a 2 months break in the Romanian championship (December to February, only friendlies, no official match). Around 20th of January, another 4 players, first team regulars even if some have Rotation contracts, start crying because they lack first team play. I promise to give them first team play, what can I do. After a week, they say that I didn't keep my promise, they are upset and they want out - I must mention that there was NO OFFICIAL GAME IN THIS PERIOD, so absolutely no possibility to give them first team play in official matches. Now my entire time is unhappy and half of them want to leave. What the... I can't even.... This game makes no sense. Try to play older versions instead, 2015 was the most balanced, since then it started becoming dumber every year.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
FM2019 is better than the catastrophe of FM2018. The dynamics feature is useful to see how the squad interacts with one another in a hierarchy. The preset selection of formations is somewhat restrictive even with a custom formation, which I use. I cannot use certain elements of gegenpressing's intensity in players' instructions when I extremely urgent pressing intensity on the team tactic on my wingers. The injuries seem to be less destructive in duration than before. From my experience, the game appears to have nerfed the one-top formations, where I used multiple variations of 4-2-3-1 as my primary formation. In a one-top formation, my world class strikers have a tough time scoring 20+ league goals in a season. Hat-tricks are extremely rare even with world class strikers, wingers, and inside forwards. Wingers cannot be relied upon for goal scoring. Without good crossing stats, the wingers and fullbacks are turrible at crosses into the box. This new world of Football Manager changes everything in my tactics and etc.

Overall, FM2019 is okay, a 6 out of 10. In my book from FM2015 to FM2019, FM2016 is the standout winner with FM2015 close behind in second.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I come from a non football mad country and have never really had any interest in the sport. However, the football manager games are well made and appeal to my analytic side. Football manager 2019 is an enjoyable game even if you are not obsessed with football.

The 2019 game has many improved features namely the training and mentoring systems, the match engine is also improved over the 2017 version which was my first football manager game.

Taking a small team and gradually improving the squad and club facilities as you progress up the divisions is a very satisfying gaming experience. If you enjoy management style games  or games that require a bit of analysis and planning, then I recommend this game even if you are not overly familiar with football.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
If SI is planning to keep playing deaf, this game totally is not worth its release price. The game is obviously the best football simulator out there and I think that is starting to get to the devs' head. Most of the additions of this year are sugar-coating and unfunctional features that improve the aesthetic aspects of the game rather than its playability. Despite all of the players' complaints on common issues regarding the game, SI mostly ignores such negative feedback and keeps on adding in unnecessary sauces without cooking a decent main dish.  

The match engine probably is the worst among the last few games. Even a top-flight team's five-star rating player can go ahead and pluck in an own goal from midfield. Your striker with top finishing skills will keep on missing the target from a yard. Your defenders will be caught dumb in almost every single counter-attack and you'll concede since they'll decide to stay away from the opponent's striker all of a sudden in the penalty box.

Most of the instructions you try to impose on your players are just ignored. 

No matter your managerial skills, some players will keep on bringing you irrational matters that'll piss them off whatever answer you give them and therefore reduce the atmosphere of the dressing room.

I personally think that it doesn't really matter that much since the game isn't meant to be realistic in graphical aspects, although the animations in the 3D match engine are really terrible and way behind the current tech. If the devs also think the same way as me, then they probably should stop focusing on such trivial matters as "improving the UI".

Although obviously, this game isn't just a piece of garbage that is full of cons, despite all of these annoying and frustrating problems that lie within, there are also tons of great stuff about the game going on (hence my playing time). The problem is that every year, while the fans expect from the devs some fixes on these problems, the devs just go on and feed us some unasked for features that they just go ahead and decide for themselves. 

The training interface is a great overhaul, really adds to the realism aspect, although might be challenging and hard to get intuitive with for new players.

Also the new tactics induction feature is a really user friendly addition to the game.

The game absolutely has one of the best player rating and scouting systems out there. It's a great way to expand your real-life knowledge on players.

The cons might appear to be outnumbering the pros of the game, although that definitely is not the case. The game is still the best football simulator out there, and tons of fun. The reason that I've written so much about the cons is that despite all the years that went by, the game is still way too far from its complete potential and it's just disappointing. 

Still, if you're a footy-head, you should totally go for the game. If it's on a sale (which was the case when I wrote this) definitely go for it. Even if it's a rainy, cold Stoke night.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
A giant leap forward in football management...

For me Football Manager is a huge time investment in an alternate world which I enjoy with a couple of years' break in between sessions.  The most recent FM game I sunk myself into was 2015, although I did buy 2016 and feel it was pretty much the same, 2019 however is not, it is a massive step into complex world.

I started playing Football Management games as a genre in the late 80s thanks to shareware bundles on 5.25' disks that my parents would give me and through the 90s favoured Player Manager (I loved seeing myself as a player at the time), Ultimate Manager (the Stadium building was awesome) and the Spanish game PC Futbol (my best mate is Spanish and ran the translations until I could figure out how to play and playing the games was fun). In the early 2000s Total Club Manager which became Fifa Manager dominated my spare time with the personal wealth building side, owning a team and having a kid come through the youth system which was a blast. My hands down personal favourite feature though was the create a club feature where I built the ficticious Portsea Pirates into perennial Champions League winners while enjoying a more modern take on some of my favourite features from earlier games including playing the matches in Fifa in 2004.

In 2012 and 2015 I sunk as much time into Football Manager as I had in earlier games and while not burning through as many years I found the level of engagement and feeling of ownership over the progress of my team to be far greater.

After a few years away from the genre I've returned and spent 45 hours playing through July and August trying to find my feet in a game that feels simply larger and more involved but the reward has meant that I cheer on forward movement and goals like never before and feel ownership and pride for the 17yo winger who just scored his first goal after the board wrote him off as a poor signing.

To my family, I am sorry...I'm awake and not at work so I'll be loading it up in a minute and will have it on all day, but thanks to the turn based nature of the time progression some semblance of real life will continue to take place in the background for the next couple of hundred hours or so while I worry about my relationship with the dressing room more than the lounge room.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
Long time player of the Football Manager Series, and I've found this years edition of the game better in many respects.  Looks good, tactics customisation seems a success, the game seems more challenging but has not been helped with some niggling annoyances.  
I've come across frustrations this year that almost made me stop playing.  I've seen defenders for no apparent reason split like the parting of the red sea and let the opposition score.  Please, please investigate the game's crossing mechanics I don't expect a Wing back / Winger to get past the defence and have a clear crossing opportunity to stop abruptly allowing the defender to catch up smash the ball against a defender.  I've also seen some suspicious games where things look seriously scripted - I'm hoping this is not the case and the engine gets looked at and refined.  It would be such a shame to put people off playing if issues are not looked into within the game engine.
I felt the game this year didn't give enough to justify the full game price.  I would still like to see them do more with the game format surely more can be done with an online format so managers can pit themselves against each other and take FM to a whole new level?  Overall a 7/10 for me, new players would like the game, veterans may feel its more of the same.

review:
Overall a good an immersive game. Not quite up to the standard of prior games in the series but a noticeable improvement on 2018. 

Scouting has been refined and made easier to use with the new system introduced last year.
Training now has meaning and depth. 
Transfers are improved with realistic, drawn out negotiations actually being part of the process. 


Only things to say are that the game engine seems to have not progressed as much as SI shouted about. Newgens also feel rather bland with similar models/hairs regardless of where they come from and their age. 

100% worth a purchase when on sale. Worth a purchase at full price but I'd probably only recommend that for experienced players of the series.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I purchased the game on a 66% discount, knowing full well that it wasn't worth the asking price, but hoped that it made enough progress since 2012 to keep me busy for weeks to come. I've previously played the 2012/2013 releases--which at the time felt like a novelty--but the 2019 release brings very little to the table, and I'm sad to say that it feels like it has a lot of recycled code from earlier releases.

In a nutshell, FM is about releasing new versions of the game each year where the main change is the updated database (players, teams, etc). The retail price is around €55 and you're not paying for a brand new game, instead, you're paying perhaps for the 10% new code. Compare this with other games, such as Sid Meier's Civilization, that are around the same price, and are released every 6-8 years, and introduce true novelty and a complexity and depth like FM could never dream of reaching, and yet Firaxis' team (which develops Civilization) is a fraction of Sports Interactive.

The take-away here is to realize that Sports Interactive cannot fix FM without recoding it from scratch and by bringing someone with great vision to take charge of the steering wheel. Recycling old code and old design is no longer feasible, nor is it charming. 

So what's the problem with FM? The main problem is that the simulation is not presented well. The presentation is done through animation and it is mainly from the animation that we, the players, ought to understand how the game works. It shouldn't be from the database. When people pointed this out in earlier releases, the hardcore fans came to the rescue by saying that despite its flaws, the game has an enormous depth that many weren't capable of understanding, and that the real depth lies in how the variables work in the background. 

This is the wrong approach. The animation should offer an accurate representation of the back-end. Period. How do we know that the animation is not working? We find out not by playing English teams, or Italian teams, or any other major football nation. We find out by picking a small football nation (in terms of its leagues, not its national team), we then pick an inferior league, and then we check how the lower-end football players interact with each other and the opposing team. We do this because it allows us to check how the smallest parts of the product works (ie the qualities of football player). 

If we were to check the best players in Premier League, for instance, it would be harder to notice the simulation deficits because a poor play coming from a high-end player, or even a poorly managed team with good players, is engineered to make sense, meaning that unlike the lower-end players, their absurdity is not showing, even though it's there. When I say absurdity, I'm refering to the poor and unrealistic decision-making that players make in order to simulate a low skill. For instance, in the 2012 release, it was usual for a poor goal-keeper to give the ball to an opponent, or for a player to kick the ball out when no one was near him. These flaws are not bugs, they're a part of the code, and Sports Interactive have been trying to paint them over by changing their behavior instead of redoing their logic. Sometimes this works fine, like when the injuries happened too often, they decreased the probability for injuries to happen; other times, it works poorly. But when it comes to decision-making, a poor player needs to simulate poor play, not absurd play.

As for micro-managing the game, the dashboard has been given a modern look but feels more confusing than older versions. To determine corner kicking and how the players should position themselves has become a mystery. Hours pass by as you click your way through and skipping the news from other leagues and your own league, and even when you choose not to be informed, you still get to click your way through a lot of nonsense.

In a multiplayer scenario it might be fun, especially if you play with friends, but in single player the game is not worth it unless you're an ardent football fan and really need the stimulation.

title: Football Manager 2019
review: People who say this game is scripted are right. The matches are highly scripted, not only matches, almost everything is highly scripted. Which transfers will go well, who will take who everything is scripted. This is one of the worst games i played. It doesnt even make sense, why do i play the match if its decided that i will lose no matter what i do? Who plays games like that? Sometimes im too bad and im scripted to win and sometimes im very very good with all my players being better than theirs, morale is higher than theirs and everything is better than them yet i lose, i load the save and i try again with different tactics and i lose again and again and again. And then another match comes up that i should absolutely lose, and i win again :D This game doesnt make sense.

review:
I have been playing Football Manager religiously since FM 2012 and this is honestly the worst game I have played by far, and i have put many hours into this game so this isn't one of those split second anger reviews. 

The match engine is awful this year. I have tried (and persisted with) many tried and tested tactics that should have suited my team but regardless of how well my players got used to a tactic, results were completely unrealistic and nonsensical. Contributing to my hate towards this years game is Strikers can't hit a barn door either, be it in a lone system or a pairing. 

I understand that FM is challenging, that's why I play the game, but this is ridiculous. Absolute waste of my money, would love to be refunded but we all know SI despise that word, and would rather blindly point me to another of their 'helpful' forums. After the loyalty of the past 7 years, I think i'll call time FM. Please save your money for literally any other game. Heard Goat Simulator was pretty good. Don't buy.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
First PC FM since the CM days. During that period, FMM was my go to.

Not sure how I feel about some of the issues I've seen so far. 

---
1. Aguero was suggested to play as an advance forward but doesn't score despite 20 odd shots per match. Changed him to a complete forward and he was became a machine. Same thing happened with Leroy (suggested to be used as a winger, but I made him an IF and he won ballon d'or) & Raz (top assist).

2.Ended one match 1-1 and the end game report stated that my GK was fortunate to get a clean sheet from the last match.
---

Despite the above and other bugs, inaccuracies & etc. it is a lot of fun and you can spend thousands of hours if you really wanted to.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
I haven't been having any of the issues other people have been talking about but I have noticed some things that may annoy you.

Overall I think this game is pretty damn good, it runs better for me than FM18, the match engine is way better (no more people shooting the ball at the corner flag, lol). I have not had any annoyances with clicks not registering and I have not had rampant injury issues that make no sense, I barely even hit the post and the most shots I've seen from one team in a game is 30 and thats when I was severely outclassed (and not even all were on target).

This game has a lot of depth, you can manage almost every aspect you like about your club, move to other clubs and influence the game around the various leagues you have loaded. Build up your youth, bring your team from the lowest division to the top, win the CL and more! I say the best way to do this is without using any exploits that some users have found, it can ruin some of the game for you and believe me you will enjoy it and feel much more rewarded when you succeed without using any exploits.

The only annoyance I really have with this game is how some players decide to sign contracts. In my save it is the year 2024 and all the wonderkids and such are now CPU generated players. France seems to have a disproportionate number of wonderkids but that aside trying to sign them is one of the stupidest experiences I have had. My club has an equal reputation in the world to Newcastle, we both matched the release clause for the player and Newcastle offered them 6.9mil/year, reasonable for an 18 year old who can already come in and dominate the league (not always ensured, you can have flops). Anyways I saved before I sent in my offer to try some things out, I offered an equal amount with standard bonuses and clauses that the player wanted, they went to Newcastle, I offered an equal amount with exploits in the bonuses (things they wont reach with a huge money sum but they will like it a lot, not sure if you call this an exploit, I do) and he still goes to Newcastle, I decide to go all out just to see if it will even work and decided to give him all of the things I said before AND a 50% salary increase per year, that is an insane amount of money I highly doubt that Newcastle would match, guess what, he went to Newcastle.

I think some of the players in this game are just fated to join a certain club unless you maybe offer them 10x what they're asking for, it makes no sense as I was in EL competition and Newcastle was nowhere near that.

Overall I do recommend this game, it plays really well for me and I haven't been running into many of the issues that other people have been,  and you probably won't either (vocal minority). Pick it up on a sale if you're reluctant, I was able to get it for $30.

title: Football Manager 2019
review:
For context, I haven't played any management sim games in decades. I usually play rogue-likes, a few RPGs, and quirky indie games. My top games are FTL, Binding of Isaac, various MMOs, any survival/crafting games. There, now you know what I normally like.

FM19 is a superb game, made by masters of the genre. Sports Interactive have been making this game for a long time, and it shows. The detail and depth in the game is astounding, and all of it is presented through a pleasing, responsive interface. As this game is basically just clicking hyperlinks, the flow of the various menus is of paramount importance, and it's done well here. There are multiple ways to get to the screen that you want, and plenty of customization of the information you want to present. It can be hard to find that one thing you're looking for sometimes, but that's just a learning curve and to be expected from a game with so much data to present.

It's thoroughly addicting. If you commit a few hours to overcome the steep learning curve at the beginning, you'll be rewarded with an experience that will last many years. If you look at streamers and fans of the series, you can see the commitment the FM series generates with it's fans. Once you get the hang of it, it's extremely hard to put down. There is a constant flow of success and failure in the game, meaning it doesn't get old. The next challenge is always right there for you. Win promotion, balance the finances, develop that new player, improve the club facilities, sign that impossible transfer, scout the new wonderkid. The list of immersive gameplay experiences is endless.

I could go on praising the game for pages, but I'll end with a pros and cons list:

PROS
Value for money. This game is worth every penny, as once you crack the learning curve, it'll give you hundreds of hours of enjoyment.

Authenticity. It is astonishing how much real life data this game has. Everything is in there - every player you've ever heard of, every manager, coach, physio. The database is staggering, and the research it must have taken to build is astounding.

Interface. To make such a wealth of data accessible to the player must have been a massive hurdle to overcome, but they've done it flawlessly. While you may occasionally get lost trying to find a piece of information, it's in there. You just haven't found it.

CONS
Audio. There is none, save for the sound of the ball being kicked, the refs whistle, and the match crowd. The vast majority of the game is completely silent. It's very confusing when you first start, as the only feedback you get from the engine is visual.

Team-talks/Dynamics. In some ways, this game is a morale manager, and while the system is deep and complex (as is everything in this game), it lacks nuance. You will often repeat the same talks over and over, changing statements so as not to bore the team, or regularly praising/criticizing them to win the numbers game. It's not bad, just repetitive, and the lack of variety in the various statements your manager can make gets old quickly. Your personality is lost when speaking to the players, as the game forces you into a few choices which may not represent what you really want to say to the squad. More depth is needed in this system.

Set pieces. The worst part of the game, for me. Apart from feeling a little broken in matches (they are ridiculously successful), the interface for creating them, changing them, and varying them is very bad. It's needlessly confusing and limited in scope. You are forced into making a few choices from a small pool, instead of organically growing your set piece plans. If you want to be inventive with your free kicks, you can't do it here.

OVERALL
Worth every penny. Experienced players may take issues with some of the changes in this version, but newbies will love it. It's a game made by masters. Great job SI!

title: Football Manager 2019
review: The AI while suppose to be enhanced is still ridden with bugs. Sports Interactive is simply putting out games and while promising more also includes more bugs. Do not get me started on player interaction off the ball. Whether players do not recognize the ball's location or whether they approach the ball at the speed of a sloth and a player farther away will sprint and tackle them and then score. The finishing of your own AI is terrible compared to that of the opposing AI. Also the heading function of this game is idiotic. Players would rather just head the ball randomly and lose possession needlessly instead of attempting to control the ball. The players inability to cross or more often just not attempting to cross at all. This game leaves a lot to be desired and I fear this might be the start to a steep decline in quality of Football Manager.
